retest this please

LGTM.

cc: @robertwb

Tested last commit (auth de/serialization) by running a simple job (80 million records, GCS to S3 and back) on the DataflowRunner with 10 workers and the following values for the awsCredentialsProvider flag:

- `'{"@type":"AWSStaticCredentialsProvider","awsAccessKeyId":"redacted","awsSecretKey":"redacted"}'`
  - Success

- `'{"@type":"ThisIsGarbage","awsAccessKeyId":"redacted","awsSecretKey":"redacted"}'`
  - Failure: java.io.IOException: AWS credential provider type 'ThisIsGarbage' is not supported

I believe most implementations of AWSCredentialsProvider are supported, but not all. There are a bunch of providers that are singletons, so they were easy to add. Unit tests confirm they should work, but I don't have a way to test them. The more complex providers are certainly within reach for someone that needs them (and can test them).

The default provider is DefaultAWSCredentialsProviderChain, which should work for a lot of development environments using DirectRunner.

I did not perform bigger tests with this auth commit because they are expensive to run and because they wouldn't prove anything about auth working or not.

Thanks to @lukecwik for an extra hand in getting through the credentials serialization.

There have been a handful of requests for various features to be included in this PR. The PR has taken months already; can we get this initial implementation submitted with the current feature set? That will unlock anyone else from submitting their own, smaller PRs to improve the S3 filesystem. For example, I have a Redshift CL that I would really like to share.
Closing this PR for now
Closing this PR for now

I think it makes sense to group it into 1 PR fixing all 3 issues and making CassandraIO split properly. Each individual fix is small and doesn't have value on its own, only in combination.

FYI, it's the approach I use in Apache Karaf and other project to override the assembly. Basically, we don't use the `apache-release` profile: instead we use our own `release` profile doing the same but overriding the assembly execution.

retest this please

I can confirm that using the original JdbcIO.write() method on the DataflowRunner does group the writes into batches. The size of one batch is at most batchSize() elements, but sometimes also smaller. This does however solve the original problem on the DirectRunner where the batches always contain only one element. I also compared the performance of the original JdbcIO.write() method with the JdbcIO.writeIterable() method on Cloud Spanner using the DataflowRunner. I could not measure any significant difference. This means that, at least as far as I'm concerned, the functionality for writeIterable() is no longer needed.
I still updated the PR based on the review and my own test results. Feel free to use (parts of) it if you see other use cases where this functionality might be needed, or otherwise just close it.

Run Java JdbcIO Performance Test

I added a test for the write with backoff: I define a lock table strategy. Then I'm starting a first insert transaction on a table. Before committing this transaction, I'm starting the pipeline which tries to insert in the same table. It results with a lock timeout. We can see the backoff used in the log (retrying). Then, in another thread, I commit the first transaction, and we can see the pipeline resumes and insert.
Run seed job
Run Java JdbcIO Performance Test

Looks like kubernetes is present on beam3 executor (it wasn't previously, so there's a progress). It probably means that it is present on all executors now but I'm not 100% sure, because I am unable to check it due to [BEAM-3480](https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/BEAM-3480). 

The current error on beam3 is due to missing kubeconfig. It's a separate issue - we have to setup a gke cluster, create a proper kubeconfig and. See: [build 225 on beam 3 executor](https://builds.apache.org/job/beam_PerformanceTests_JDBC/225/console) and the issue regarding the cluster provisioning: [BEAM-3561](https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/BEAM-3561)

We should not merge this PR because of the above issues. It was just to make sure what the kubernetes status is.

The sdks/java/build-tools/src/main/resources/beam/suppressions.xml explicitly excludes everything generated in target/generated-sources.
master currently breaks on `mvn clean install` because of this. Notice that this was not detected before because the artifacts for the SNAPSHOT already existed.
